484d9a333b4254618d5a2b3f9632b3b03541da57.name: Communication Skills.pdf
484d9a333b4254618d5a2b3f9632b3b03541da57.content:
[Page 1]
COMMUNICATION SKILLS

[Page 2]
WHAT IS COMMUNICATION?
1. Communication istheprocess ofsharing ideas, feelings, orinformation between two
ormore people .
2. Itistheway people send andreceive messages tounderstand each other .
3. Communication means exchanging thoughts orknowledge through speaking, writing,
orother signals .
4. Itistheactoftransferring information from oneperson orplace toanother .
5. Communication istheprocess ofconnecting with others toexpress needs, opinions,
oremotions .

[Page 3]
SKILL
Theword Skill canbedefined as:
1. SKILL means theability andcapability ofanindividual toperform thejobwell.
2. SKILL means toperform thegiven task with fullexpertise bringing theproductive
results .
3. Askill istheability todosomething well, usually gained through practice ortraining .
4. Itistheknowledge andtalent needed toperform ataskeffectively .
5. Askill issomething you candevelop and improve toperform work oractivities
successfully .

[Page 4]
WHAT IS COMMUNICATION SKILL?
1. Communication skill istheability toshare ideas andinformation clearly soothers
canunderstand you.
2. Itisthetalent ofexpressing thoughts and feelings effectively through speaking,
writing, orbody language .
3. Communication skill means listening carefully andresponding inaway thatbuilds
understanding .
4. Itisthecapability toconnect with people byusing words, gestures, andexpressions
inaproper manner .
5. Communication skill istheartofexchanging messages inaway that isclear,
respectful, andmeaningful .

[Page 5]
IMPORTANCE OF COMMUNICATION SKILLS
1. Builds Understanding :Good communication helps people understand each other
clearly andavoid confusion .
2. Strengthens Relationships :Itimproves personal and professional relationships by
creating trust andrespect .
3. Boosts Confidence :Strong communication skills make iteasier toexpress ideas and
opinions confidently .
4. Helps inCareer Growth :Employers value good communicators because they can
share ideas, lead teams, andsolve problems effectively .
5. Supports Learning :Clear communication makes iteasier togive and receive
instructions, feedback, andknowledge .

[Page 6]
CONTINUE
6. Resolves Conflicts: Good communication helps solve disagreements peacefully by
listening and explaining calmly.
7. Encourages Teamwork: It allows people to work together smoothly and achieve
common goals.

[Page 7]
EXAMPLES
➢Job Interview: Explaining your qualifications clearly to impress the interviewer.
➢Classroom: Asking questions and sharing ideas with the teacher to understand
lessons better.
➢Workplace: Giving clear instructions to your team so a project is completed on time.
➢Friendship: Talking openly to solve a misunderstanding with a friend.
➢Public Speaking: Presenting a topic to an audience in a way that everyone can
follow.
➢Customer Service: Politely answering a customer’s questions to keep them satisfied.
➢Family Discussion: Expressing feelings respectfully during a family meeting to avoid
conflict.

[Page 8]
LISTENING SKILL
Listening skill is the ability to carefully hear, understand, and respond to what someone is saying. It means focusing on the speaker’s words, feelings, and message instead of just waiting to reply. Good listening requires attention, patience, and an open mind. Barriers to Listening
1. Distractions: Noise, phone notifications, or other people talking can break concentration.
2. Lack of Focus: Daydreaming or thinking about something else while someone is speaking.
3. Prejudice or Bias: Judging the speaker’s appearance, accent, or opinion before listening.
4. Interrupting: Cutting the speaker off to give your own thoughts.
5. Language Problems: Not understanding the words or vocabulary being used.
6. Emotional Reactions: Getting angry or upset instead of calmly listening.

[Page 9]
WAYS TO REMOVE BARRIERS
To become a better listener, you can:
1. Stay Focused: Give full attention to the speaker and avoid multitasking.
2. Reduce Distractions: Turn off phones, lower background noise, and maintain eye
contact.
3. Be Open -Minded: Listen without judging or forming an opinion too quickly.
4. Wait Before Responding: Allow the speaker to finish before you reply.
5. Ask Questions: If something is unclear, politely ask for clarification.
6. Practice Active Listening: Nod, use facial expressions, or repeat key points to show
understanding.

[Page 10]
ACTIVE LISTENING
Active listening is a way of listening where you give full attention to the speaker and
show that you truly understand their message. It is more than just hearing words —it
means focusing on the speaker’s feelings, asking questions, and giving feedback to show
interest. Key Features of Active Listening:
1. Full Attention: Looking at the speaker and avoiding distractions like phones or side
conversations.
2. Understanding: Trying to catch both the meaning and emotions behind the words.
3. Feedback: Nodding, smiling, or saying small words like “I see” or “That makes
sense” to show you are following.
4. Clarification: Asking questions or repeating key points to make sure you understood
correctly.
5. Non-Judgment: Listening without interrupting or criticizing the speaker.

[Page 11]
Active Listening comprises of the following:
➢Stop talking and start listening
➢Focus attention on Speaker & avoid any distraction
➢Maintain eye -contact
➢Listen for central ideas
➢Establish Rapport.
➢Check your emotions to avoid any bias
➢Concentrate on what the Speaker is saying. Focus your attention on key points,
concepts, and feelings displayed in the message.

[Page 12]
➢Suspend your judgements and avoid jumping to conclusion without first listening the
speaker fully.
➢Listen for the main points, key ideas and important messages.
➢Look for areas of interest, and agreement. If you have to disagree agreeably by
criticizing the ideas but not the speaker.
➢Do not jump to the conclusion.
➢Ask questions for clarification.
➢Summarize what you understand, what is other person is saying.
➢Take notes to remember what is said.

[Page 13]
PROCESS OF LISTENING
Listening is an active process through which we receive, understand, interpret, and
respond to spoken messages. It involves both hearing and understanding what is said. The process of listening can be divided into five main stages :
1. Receiving (Hearing)
➢This is the first stage , where the listener hears the sound of the speaker’s words.
➢It involves paying attention and recognizing the sounds, tone, and pitch of the
message. Example: You hear your teacher explaining a topic in class.

[Page 14]
2. Understanding (Comprehending)
➢At this stage, the listener tries to understand the meaning of the words or message.
➢It involves interpreting vocabulary, grammar, and context to make sense of what is heard. Example: You understand what your teacher means when she says, “The test will be on Friday.”
3. Evaluating (Interpreting or Judging)
➢Here, the listener analyzes and judges the message.
➢You decide whether the message is true, logical, or important. Example: You think about whether the information your friend gave you is correct or not.

[Page 15]
4. Responding (Reacting)
➢After understanding and evaluating, the listener gives feedback —either verbally or
nonverbally.
➢This can be a nod, smile, question, or spoken reply. Example: You nod in agreement or say, “Yes, I understand.”
5. Remembering (Retaining)
➢The final stage is storing the information in memory for future use.
➢Good listeners remember important details from the conversation. Example: You recall your teacher’s instructions when preparing for the test.

[Page 16]
TYPES OF LISTENING
1. Active Listening
Focusing completely on the speaker, understanding the message, and responding
thoughtfully. Example: A student paying attention to a teacher’s lecture, taking notes, and asking
questions.
2. Passive Listening
Hearing the words but not giving full attention or feedback. Example: Listening to background music while doing homework.
3. Critical Listening
Listening carefully to evaluate or judge what is being said. Example: Listening to a politician’s speech to decide whether to support their ideas.

[Page 17]
CONTINUE
5. Appreciative Listening
Listening for enjoyment or pleasure. Example: Enjoying a favorite song, a poem recital, or a storytelling session.
6. Selective Listening
Hearing only parts of the message that interest you and ignoring the rest. Example: A child listening only when their parent mentions “chocolate”
during a long talk.

[Page 18]
READING SKILL
1. Reading skill is the ability to recognize, understand, and interpret written words
and sentences to get meaning from a text.
2. Reading skill means the process of decoding written symbols to understand ideas,
information, and emotions expressed by the writer.
3. Reading skill is the process of getting meaning from written or printed text
through understanding words, sentences, and ideas.
4. Reading skill refers to the capacity to interpret and analyze written language
effectively for learning and communication.

[Page 19]
TECHNIQUES OF READING/ TYPES
Reading techniques are methods or strategies that help readers understand, analyze, and remember what
they read. The main techniques of reading are:
1. Skimming
Definition:
Skimming means reading quickly to get the main idea or general overview of a text without focusing on
every word. Purpose:
It helps to understand the overall theme or central idea of a passage quickly. How to Do It:
➢Read the title, headings, and subheadings .
➢Look at the first and last sentences of paragraphs.
➢Notice key words , dates, or names. Example:
When you pick up a newspaper article, you may skim it to know what it’s about —for example, “The
article talks about climate change in Pakistan.”

[Page 20]
2. Scanning
Definition:
Scanning means reading quickly to find specific information or details such as
numbers, names, or dates. Purpose:
It helps to locate a particular piece of information without reading the entire text. How to Do It:
➢Mov

9b63dd1f33b7da7cb311e4d055e1e92d08f65f3c.name: Non-Verbal-Communication main.pptx
9b63dd1f33b7da7cb311e4d055e1e92d08f65f3c.content:
[Slide 1]

Non-Verbal Communication

Presented By: Hammad Naeem

Roll no : 24CYS40

[Slide 2]

Introduction: What is Non-Verbal Communication? Nonverbal communication refers to the ways in which beings convey information about their emotions, needs, intentions, attitudes, and thoughts without the use of verbal language. NVC often reveals our true feelings and intentions more than words do. Agar koi kehta hai “Main theek hoon” lekin uska chehra udaas ho, awaaz dukhi ho, to uski body language asal jazbaat bata deti hai ke wo theek nahi ha

. NVC is crucial across all cultures, encouraging positive interactions and understanding. Agar do log alag mulkon se milte hain aur ek doosre ki zubaan nahi samajhte, phir bhi muskurahat, aankhon ka contact, ya haath milana jaise gestures se unke darmiyan positive connection ban jata hai

[Slide 3]

Defining the Channels of Communication

Non-verbal communication uses silent signals to interact with the world. Non-verbal communication mein hum bolte nahi, balkay muskurahat, aankhon ka contact, ya body language se apni feelings dikhate hain

Intentional Signals

Conscious actions like waving goodbye or nodding in agreement. Jese kisi ko haath hila ke “bye” kehna ya sar hila ke “haan” kehna

Unintentional Cues

Subconscious signals, such as crossing arms when nervous or a tense facial expression when stressed. Subconscious signals wo hote hain jo hum bina soche samjhe dikhate hain, jaise nervous hone par arms cross karna aur stress mein tense chehra. Context is Key

How NVC is understood depends on the situation, like a hug being appropriate in one setting but not another. NVC ko samajhna situation par depend karta hai; jaise funeral mein muskurana inappropriate hoga, lekin birthday party ya celebration mein muskurana bilkul theek aur natural hai.

[Slide 4]

The Power of Non-Verbal Cues

Non-verbal communication shapes initial perceptions and improves relationships. Building Trust

Consistent NVC establishes credibility and trust. Agar tum hamesha eye contact aur positive gestures use karte ho, log tum par bharosa karenge

Expressing Confidence

A firm handshake or open stance projects authority. Job interview mein seedha khade hona aur haath milana tumhari self-assurance dikhata hai

Emotional Clarity

NVC conveys subtle emotions beyond words. Muskurahat ya slightly tilted head friendliness aur interest dikhata hai

[Slide 5]

The Seven Dimensions of Silent Communication

Non-verbal cues are essential in shaping perceptions. Mastering these areas gives you greater control over how you are perceived. Facial Expressions

Show emotions like happiness, sadness, or surprise. A smile conveys warmth, a frown indicates concern. Gestures

Hand and arm movements emphasize points. A thumbs-up means approval, pointing directs attention. Posture & Movement

How we stand and move reveals confidence or tension. Upright posture suggests assurance, slumped shoulders might show nervousness. Eye Contact

Shows attention and engagement. Direct eye contact conveys honesty, while avoiding it might signal discomfort. Appearance

Clothing, grooming, and style signal professionalism or personality. A sharp suit projects authority, casual attire suggests relaxation. Tone of Voice (Paralanguage)

The pitch, speed, and volume of speech convey meaning beyond words. A calm tone reassures, a quick pace might show excitement. Touch (Haptics)

Physical contact like a handshake or a pat on the back. A firm handshake indicates respect, a gentle touch offers comfort. Space (Proxemics)

The physical distance maintained between people. Close proximity suggests intimacy, while greater distance indicates formality.

[Slide 6]

Focus on the Face: Universal Facial Expressions

Facial expressions are a globally understood way to instantly reveal our emotional state. Surprise

Wide eyes, raised brows, and an open mouth signal unexpected events. Joy

A true smile engages both the eyes and mouth, clearly showing happiness. Anger

Furrowed brows, tense lips, and a fixed stare convey strong displeasure.

[Slide 7]

The Power of Posture and Body Movement

Body language, or Kinesics, reveals our inner state through posture and movement, influencing how we are perceived. Open vs. Closed Posture

Open posture (uncrossed arms, visible hands) signals receptiveness. Closed posture (crossed arms) suggests defensiveness. The Confidence Indicator

Standing tall with shoulders back projects confidence and authority. A steady stance indicates engagement. Fidgeting & Tension

Fidgeting (like tapping feet or playing with hair) often reveals nervousness, anxiety, or boredom.

[Slide 8]

Connecting Through Eye Contact and Tone

Eye Contact (Oculesics)

Maintain steady, engaged eye contact to show attentiveness, honesty, and respect. A lack of eye contact can signal disinterest. Tone of Voice (Paralanguage)

Your tone—not just words—conveys emotion and intent. A soft, steady tone shows composure, while varied pitch and volume keep listeners engaged.

[Slide 9]

Non-Verbal Communication in Professional Contexts

In the workplace, effective non-verbal signals can determine career success. They are especially critical during job interviews, presentations, and team meetings. Project confidence and engagement through upright posture and attentive body language. Engage your audience and project credibility with a confident smile and deliberate gestures. Show active listening and value for colleagues' input through nodding and positive facial expressions. A study found that non-verbal cues account for 55% of the message impact in face-to-face communication.

[Slide 10]

Mastering Non-Verbal Communication: Your Lasting Impact

Actions Speak Louder Than Words

Non-verbal communication is not just a supplement; it's the foundation of profound influence. By consciously honing your body language, vocal tone, and facial expressions, you unlock unparalleled credibility and connection, creating memorable impressions. Cultivate Awareness

Recognize your own non-verbal habits and accurately interpret others' cues. Achieve Alignment

Ensure perfect harmony between your words and non-verbal cues for authentic and powerful messaging. Maximize Impact

Leverage non-verbal signals strategically to forge positive, lasting impressions in every interaction.

[Slide 11]

[Slide 12]
